Exercise 

Working with words 

 A. Find the words from the text that match with the following meanings. 

 a. Shuffling : walking by dragging one's feet along or without lifting them fully from the ground 

b. Doodling : drawing pictures or patterns while thinking about something else 

c.  Plaque: a piece of flat metal with writing on it 

d. Percept : a general rule intended to regulate behaviour or thought 

e. Sneak : move or go in a furtive or stealthy way 


B. Consult your teacher and define the following thinking skills. 

a. convergent thinking

= Convergent thinking is a type of thinking focused on finding a single correct or "best" solution to a problem. Tests like multiple choice, standardized tests, quizzes, and spelling tests require convergent thinking because there is only one completely correct answer. 


b. divergent thinking 

= Divergent thinking is when you come up with many different possible answers or ideas for an open-ended question or problem. It encourages thinking outside the box and coming at problems from different angles.


c. critical thinking 

= Critical thinking means carefully analyzing, judging, and combining information and ideas in a logical way based on facts and evidence. It involves questioning your assumptions, identifying biases, and making reasoned decisions based on proof.


d. creative thinking 

= Creative thinking is thinking differently than usual and exploring new ways of problem-solving instead of sticking to tried and true methods. 


Comprehension 

 Answer the following questions. 

a. Who was Jack? How did he make children laugh? 

Jack was a friednly and kind-hearted kid who used to make children laugh childrens by cracking jokes and riddles.


b. Why are “Sharks” important to Reid? 

Sharks are important to Reid because they help to keep the ocean clean by eating dead organisms.


c. What does Mr. Browne think about the most important thing? 

Mr. Browne thinks that the most important thing is to know ownself, or own character's and evaluate them to bring out the best version of someone.


d. What is that has not been noticed by the student? 

" The message in the notice board of the school entrance gate" that writes - "Know Thyself" was the thing that has not been noticed by any student.


e. How did Jack make fun of the English class? 

Jack made fun of the English class by sarcastically answering the teacher's question of "Why are you here?". He answered in a funny way that they were there to attend English class while the answer was sensitive.


f. What were the students going to do at the end of the month? 

Students were going to submit the essay on the basis of the precepts that the teacher wrote as ' Mr. Browne's Precepts.'


g. What particular act of students surprised a girl student? 

Students used to come up with their very own personal precept, write it on a postcard, and mail it to Mr. Brownie (English Teacher) after their graduation, this thing surprised the girl student.


Critical thinking 

 a. Have you made your own precept after you read this lesson? What is it? Share it with your friends. 

= Precept is a rule or principle that we make to conduct our behaviour in accordance with that. I also had many precepts even before reading this lesson. The major precepts of my life are: 

'Anything that happens, happens for good'

'Always stay Positive'

'Believe in Karma rather than fate'

'What we are today is the result the choices we made yesterday, so we have to make choices wisely'


These are some of the precepts which I don't only think are ideal but also try to ideally follow them in my daily behaviours. 


b. According to Josh Lanyon, “If there was one life skill everyone on the planet needed, it was the ability to think with critical objectivity.” Justify this statement with your logic.

= Josh Lanyon said that the most useful life skill is being able to think critically without bias. Critical thinking lets us look at information objectively so we can decide what's best without emotions getting in the way. This helps with all kinds of choices in life. It helps us break big problems down and look at possible solutions fairly. This is important for dealing with challenges. Many fights happen because of misunderstandings if we see different sides. Critical thinking helps understand other views to fix problems in a constructive way. In online world, it's hard to tell what's real because of too much info and opinions. Critical thinking helps us separate facts from nonsense.


In conclusion, being able to analyze without prejudice is a very useful skill that helps in life in many important areas like decisions, education, relationships and being a responsible community member. 


Grammar

Question Tag

Dear friend,


I wanted to tell you about one of the most interesting classes I've had so far this semester. Yesterday we covered the topic of renewable energy sources in my Environmental Science class.


Our professor started the lecture by going over the different types of renewable energy like solar, wind, hydroelectric, geothermal, and biomass. It was fascinating to learn about the science behind how each one generates electricity. For example, did you know that solar panels work by using the photovoltaic effect to convert sunlight directly into electricity?


After the overview, we spent the rest of the class doing a group project where we had to imagine designing a full renewable energy system for a small town. My group chose to focus on wind and solar. We researched the average wind speeds and sunlight hours for the area and used that data to calculate how many wind turbines and solar panel arrays we would need. It was really interesting to think through the real-world challenges of transitioning an entire community to clean energy. Our professor said most of the work we did could actually be applied to real renewable energy projects. Overall it was one of the most engaging classes I've had so far.

Talk to you soon,

Comprehension 

 A. The headings of the first five paragraphs of the above text are given below. Write paragraph numbers next to them. 

a. Patriarchal family  = 3rd Paragraph

b. Functions of the family = 2nd Paragraph

B. Answer the following questions. 

 a. What type of family is thought to be the oldest form of the family? 

= The oldest form of the family is known as a nuclear family. It consists of parents and their children and is considered the earliest type of family.


b. How does a family provide security to its members? 

= Security is a major benefit of a family, both physically and mentally. If necessary, a strong family will provide protection against pressures from the outside world and provide its members the confidence they need to confront various challenges.


c. What were the features of a medieval European family? 

= The main feature of the Medieval European family is that it was male-dominated and extended.


d. What caused the dissolution of extended families in the West? 

= When it comes to changing family structures in Western countries, industrialisation is the main reason, along with urbanization has brought about and continues to bring about numerous new developments. Unmarried youths in particular abandoned rural areas to work in factories in metropolitan areas. As a result of this procedure, a number of extended families were dissolved.


e. What change occurred in gender roles in the modern family that emerged after the Industrial Revolution? 

= Originarily, the industrial revolution led to a domestication of women, as men went to occupations in other sectors and women were expected to care for the children. Similarly, Family responsibilities that were previously believed to be entirely male or female were changed into shared responsibilities. Also, As divorce rates rose, so did the number of one-parent families.


f. What is family law? 

= Legal problems related to family relationships, such as adoption and divorce, are dealt with under the field of law, which is called family law. Children's issues are handled by family law attorneys as well as other relevant legal issues.


g. How is modern marriage defined? 

= Simply modern marriages are defined as such marriages where the husband and wife share responsibilities. Traditional weddings have trapped the couples into their predetermined roles without a choice. Modern marriages make individual choices possible. The couples are regarded as equal partners and women have a role in decision-making for the family.


h. What do special family courts try to do? 

= Family court is a special court for legal issues originating from family connections. The family court is typically a combination of various kinds of courts, such as the courts and orphan courts, which deal with specific family issues such as matrimonial issues, spousal property, the legitimacy of any person, maintenance, guardianship of the person or custody of or access to any minor.


i. What does the legislation on child labour and child abuse declare? 

= The legislation on child labour and child abuse declares that 'No child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or employed in any hazardous employment.' It further asserts on child interest-based behaviours to be done and of free education and health care.


j. What is common among most legal systems regarding property? 

= In most legal systems a departed family member can deal with property sharing. The will or legacy describes the decedents' desires for such distribution, however, what appears to be irrational or unfair provisions could be opposed by the spouse or child survivors. In case property is not claimed, there are also laws which recognize family claims (i.e., with no will to determine its distribution).


Critical thinking 

 a. What changes have started to occur in Nepali families in recent days? What impacts will they bring on society? Discuss. 

= Nepali families are changing in today's world. While traditions of the past still have influence, new ways are developing.


In the past, things like marriage were decided more by parents. Now young people often choose their own partners, like through schools or friend groups. Divorce is more common too as people make their own choices. 


Families used to live together with parents, children and grandparents all under one roof. Now more young couples want their own small family, just parents and kids. This nuclear family is separate from other relatives.


Women have more freedoms now. They aren't just stuck at home, they can work or study too. In families, men and women share responsibilities and decisions.


A nuclear family means the kids are closer to parents. Parents can make their own rules too. It is also easier financially sometimes for a small family. Moms have more time just for kids.


But there are downsides too. Alone in a nuclear family, there is no help from grandparents or others in emergencies. Kids miss out on learning culture and values from all relatives together. Moms have a lot to do alone without support. Dads work long hours too, so kids can feel lonely or neglected.


Overall, Nepali families and society are adjusting to these new changes in family structures and roles. Both benefits and challenges arise from women's roles expanding and families becoming more nuclear and independent. Traditions from the past continue to shape things too in this transition period.


b. We see many elderly people in the elderly homes these days in Nepal. Some of them are abandoned while others live there willingly. Do you think Nepali people are deviating from their traditional culture? Give reasons.

= Nowadays in Nepal, we see a lot of elderly people living in homes for the elderly. Some of them have been abandoned by their families, while others choose to live there. This situation makes us wonder if Nepali people are moving away from their traditional culture.


The truth is, many people in our society have become focused on making money and acquiring material possessions. In the past, we used to live in extended families where elders were respected and cherished. But now, with the rise of nuclear families and the trend of having only one child, things have changed. People prioritize their own happiness and often neglect everything else, including their elderly parents.


This sad state of affairs for older people and the decline of family values can be attributed to the influence of Western culture and materialistic beliefs. Additionally, factors such as greed, the pursuit of education, and the process of industrialization have also contributed to the neglect of the elderly. People are busy with their jobs and have little time to take care of their aging parents. As a result, even parents themselves may choose not to live with their children out of fear of being neglected.


In conclusion, it's not that Nepali people are intentionally deviating from their traditional culture. Rather, the fast-paced nature of modern life, the demands of work, and the desire for small or nuclear families have led to the sorry state of older people in our society.


Writing

a. Write an essay on The Importance of Family.

Importance of Family

The family is the basic unit of society and plays a pivotal role in everyone's life. A strong family provides love, care, support, and guidance to its members. It helps shape our character and personality from a young age. Family teaches us important values like compassion, sharing, honesty and respect.


Family is very important to me. My family provides unconditional love, support and acceptance. No matter what challenges I face, I know I can count on them. They have been there through all my happy and difficult times.


Family is also important for society. Strong families create a stable community. Children raised in caring families do better and become productive adults. Families teach values like kindness and responsibility. When families struggle, it can lead to issues like poverty and crime.


In the future, family structures may change with technology. Not as many people may have traditional families. Long distance relationships may be more common due to globalization. However, family will still be essential. While families may look different, the love and support of family will remain key for people's well-being.


In conclusion, family is critical both personally and for society. Personally, my family means everything to me. And communities rely on strong families too. Even as society changes with time, family will always be hugely important for individual lives and the greater good of all. Cherishing family relationships remains key.


b. Some individuals believe that living in a nuclear family is preferable. Others believe that living with extended relatives is preferable. What are your thoughts? Write an essay comparing and contrasting the benefits and drawbacks of each.

There are two main types of family living arrangements - nuclear families and extended families. A nuclear family typically consists of parents and children, while an extended family includes additional relatives like grandparents, aunts, uncles and cousins living together.


Nuclear families have some advantages. Living on your own provides privacy and independence where each person has their own space. It also promotes close relationships between parents and children since attention is not divided among other relatives. However, nuclear families can lack a wider support system and feelings of loneliness may occur especially as parents get older without other family help.


Extended families also have benefits. A larger household means a stronger support system where relatives can help each other financially, emotionally and with caregiving duties. Kids get to learn and bond across generations. Living together fosters a sense of community and belonging within the family.


But extended families can come with disadvantages too. Having many people together under one roof risks disagreements and loss of personal boundaries. Independence and alone time is reduced in a big household.


Ultimately, the best option depends on individual needs, cultures and situations. Some value independence of nuclear families more while others prefer the companionship of extended families. Open communication within the family is important to make either arrangement work well. Both can be good if handled properly to support family bonding and well-being.

Project Work 

Work in groups. Find some elderly couples or a widow/widower staying apart from their children because they are abandoned. Ask them what they had expected from their children and what actually happened. Prepare a story and present it to the class.

Good morning everyone. My group and I recently had the opportunity to speak with an elderly couple, Mr. and Mrs. Singh, as part of our project on understanding the expectations and realities of care for the elderly.


When they were younger, the Singhs hoped that in their old age, they would be able to live peacefully with their children and grandchildren surrounding them. They looked forward to imparting their wisdom and being able to help out with childcare occasionally. Their expectation was that their children would take care of them financially and emotionally in their retirement.


Unfortunately, reality turned out to be quite different. Both their children now have careers in different cities far away due to job opportunities. While they visit on holidays, the Singhs mentioned it's a struggle with health issues living alone now. They rely on a fixed pension income which is becoming insufficient with rising living costs. Although their children send some money, it does not cover all expenses.


Loneliness and lack of regular company have been difficult to cope with. Simple tasks like grocery shopping or visiting the doctor have become challenging without any help. Both their mental and physical health has declined significantly living apart from family in their old apartment.


By sharing their story, the Singhs hope to create more awareness about the hardships faced by many elderly people who are separated from children. The experience has been very emotionally distressing for them to see their expectations of care and support in old age unmet. They wish that families could find a way to look after aging parents even with other commitments.


In conclusion, this story highlights the importance of fulfilling filial responsibilities and the impact on quality of life when expectations are not met. I hope it provides a window into the challenges the elderly population faces. Thank you for listening to our presentation.

Exercise

Working with words 

 A. Many English words are from other languages, such as redemption in the news above comes from the Latin word redimere, a combination of re(d)-, meaning “back,” and emere, meaning “buy.” Now, find out the origin and the meaning of the following words from text.


Penalty - late 14th century: from late Latin paenalitas, from paena 'punishment'. It means a punishment for breaking a rule.


Anthem - 15th century: from late Latin anthemus, from Greek anthos 'flower'. It refers to a song of celebration, praise, or patriotism.


Podium - 18th century: from Greek podion 'small foot'. It denotes a raised platform for public speakers.


Major - 14th century: from Latin maior 'greater'. It means importantly large in size or extent.


Dejection - 15th century: from Latin deiectio, from deicere 'to throw down'. It implies a state of hopeless unhappiness and despondency.


Tournament - 13th century: from Old French tornement, from torner 'to turn'. It refers to a series of contests among knights or teams, sometimes involving combat.


Stadium - mid-17th century: from Latin, from Greek stadion. It denotes a sports ground or arena with seating for spectators.


Jubilant - 15th century: from Latin iubilant-, iubilans, present participle of iubilare 'to celebrate noisily, shout joyfully'. It means celebrating something enthusiastically.


Reminiscent - 17th century: from Latin reminiscent-, from reminisci 'to recall to mind'. It refers to bringing back memories of something past.


Trophy - 15th century: via French from Latin tropaeum, from Greek tropaion. It denotes an item such as a cup or medal awarded to a winner.


Record - 14th century: from Old French recorder 'to draw, write down, tell' and directly from Latin recordari 'to remember'. It means an achievement or experience worth remembering and writing down.


Incredible - 15th century: from Latin incredibilis, from in- 'not' + credibilis 'believable'. It describes something too extraordinary and improbable to be believed.


Defender - 15th century: from Latin defensor 'protector'. It refers to a person or thing that protects or maintains something.


Suave - 17th century: from Latin suāvis 'sweet smelling, pleasant'. It describes someone attractive, charming and sophisticated.


Savor - 14th century: from Old French savour, from Latin sapor-, sapōr- 'flavor, taste'. It means to enjoy something, especially the taste of food or wine, fully and sensuously.


B. Consult a dictionary and define the following terms related to cricket. 


Wicket: Two sets of three sticks (stumps) standing upright at each end of the pitch, with two crosspieces (bails) balanced on top.


Stumps: The three upright sticks that make up a wicket.


Crease: The lines marked on the pitch to determine limits for fielding positions and runs.


Boundary: The edge of the playing area, and any sign or object that marks that edge. Hitting the ball over the boundary scores runs.


Sixer: When a batter hits the ball over the boundary without it touching the ground, scoring six runs.


Googly: A type of delivery by a wrist-spin bowler that spins in the opposite direction to their normal spin.


Leg-bye: An extra run scored when the ball deflects off the batter's body (except the bat) and they cross or are inprocess of crossing between the wickets while the ball is in play.


Maiden: An over where the bowler concedes no runs.


Pitch: The central strip of finely mown grass on the cricket field where the game is played.


Power-play: Specific fielding restrictions in limited overs cricket during the first 10 overs (usually) of each innings to encourage more scoring.


No-ball: An illegal delivery that allows the batting team an extra run with no ball additionally being re-bowled.


Yorker: A type of delivery that hits the ground very close to the batter's feet, making it difficult to hit.


C. Pronunciation

/ai/ ➡ fine, shine, bright, might, five, why, sight, white, by,

/ei/ ➡ rein, rail, sleigh, break, freight, eight, game, claim, friend, gait, hail, frame 


Comprehension 

 A. State whether the following sentences are True or False or Not Given. 

a. England was the champion of 1996 World Cup Football. = False

b. Italy bagged its first Euro Cup trophy in the Euro Cup 2020. = False

c. The English team has won more trophies in International Football than Italy. = False

B. Answer the following questions. 

a) Why does the reporter say that England is waiting to heal its half-century long pain?

The reporter says England is waiting to heal its long pain because the last time England won a major football tournament match was in 1966. The long pain means being sad and disappointed about losing many matches for a long time.


b) How did the Italian players react as soon as they became the champions?

As soon as Italy became the champions, the Italian players started happily shouting 'It's coming to Rome' which is their capital city. They were jokingly copying the song of the English football team which means football is coming home.


c) Why did Saka and Sancho cry?

Saka and Sancho cried because England lost the match in the penalty shootout. Both players missed their penalty kicks which helped Italy win.


d) Penalty shoot-out has long been a bitter experience for the English team. Why?

England loses many matches in penalty shootouts. In Euro 2020, the young player Saka missed the last penalty kick which let Italy win. Other England players like Rashford and Sancho also missed penalty kicks before. This happened three times, so penalty shootouts always end badly for England.

Yes, this applies to the Italian football team. After failing to qualify for the World Cup, the team worked very hard for four years to improve. They had a positive attitude and never gave up. Under coach Roberto Mancini, the players developed their skills and strategies. Even after losses, they learned from their mistakes and focused on the next game. Through dedication and teamwork, they were able to win the Euro Cup. So the Italian team was able to turn their failure into success by taking every match as a new chance to improve.


b. When a team plays in a home ground, it gets a huge support from the audience in the stadium. Does this support them to win the match or the players may feel pressure to win and thus lose? What do you think?

However, sometimes players may also feel pressure to win for their fans. If they are too anxious about not losing in front of the home crowd, it could negatively impact their game. They may make more mistakes due to nervousness. Overall, home support is generally an advantage, but players need to stay focused on playing their best without worrying too much about the result or what fans think. Title : Argentina beats Brazil in the COPA America Cup.


By Reuters


RIO DE JANEIRO - Argentina defeated host Brazil 1-0 tonight at the Maracana Stadium to win the Copa America, claiming their first major title in 28 years and denying Brazil a record-breaking 15th South American championship.


An early goal from Angel Di Maria proved to be the difference as Argentina withstood heavy pressure from Brazil in the second half to secure victory. The win also delivers Argentina superstar Lionel Messi his first ever senior international trophy with the national team.


Di Maria scored in the 22nd minute after a gorgeous pass by Rodrigo De Paul. From outside the box, Di Maria sent a low, left-footed shot to the far corner, giving Argentina the lead.

With the victory, Argentina wins their 15th Copa America title, drawing level with Brazil for the most wins in the history of the tournament. It is a crushing defeat for Brazil on home soil and delivers Lionel Scaloni's Argentina side their first title since 1993.


C. We can see many countries competing to host the great international sport events like the World Cup Football. But, there are arguments that hosting an event like World Cup Football can have more problems than benefits. What do you think? Write your arguments in favour or against hosting an international sport event in about 500 words.

=  Every coin has two sides. There are reasonable arguments on both sides of this issue. Hosting a major international event like the FIFA World Cup can provide significant economic and publicity benefits to the host country and cities. However, it also requires massive investments of money and resources which do not always generate good returns.


On the benefits side, a World Cup brings thousands of international visitors and media attention to the host nation. This influx of tourism spending can give a boost to the local hospitality and travel industries in cities hosting games. New hotels, transport infrastructure and facilities are often constructed to handle the spike in visitors, leaving a lasting legacy. Additionally, the prestigious image of hosting a global spectacle is seen as a point of national pride that can promote the host country on the world stage.


However, the costs of hosting a World Cup are extremely high and often underestimated. Building or renovating huge stadiums, highways, airports, subway lines and other supporting infrastructure requires multibillion-dollar investments by host governments that may not generate an adequate economic return. Many of the construction projects are "white elephants" with little use after the event ends. Mega events have also been blamed for displacing local residents and small businesses to make way for new developments. There are also security and logistical challenges in hosting such a large-scale event, as proven by issues at past World Cups.


The late delivery or overbudget expenditures on infrastructure have plagued several past hosts like Brazil in 2014. This misuse of taxpayer money has led critics to argue that investment in education, healthcare or social services may have provided better long-term returns for citizens. There is also no guarantee that the expected tourism revenues will fully cover all event-related expenditures. Several economic studies point out the limited or short-term nature of any financial boost from these global sporting jamborees.


On balance, while hosting a FIFA World Cup offers opportunities for national prestige and tourism income, the extraordinary costs are often too high for countries - especially developing nations - relative to the hard-to-predict economic benefits. A cost-benefit analysis studying concrete legacy outcomes is needed before a bid is launched to ensure taxpayer funds are well spent rather than wasted on "white elephants". With better planning and fiscal responsibility, international events can generate more profits relative to their price tag. But unrealistic projections of financial bonanzas should always be viewed skeptically.


In conclusion, while international sporting events offer publicity positives, the huge financial and social costs typically outweigh the benefits - especially in smaller developing countries. More rigorous cost-benefit analyses are needed before nations commit billions to hosting a global jamboree that may just become an expensive distraction from long-term social development priorities.

 Comprehension 

 Answer the following questions.

a. What is a hyperloop? How does it work?

A hyperloop is a high-speed train that travels inside a tube with no air. It can reach incredible speeds because there is no air resistance to slow it down.


b. How is hyperloop more beneficial than traditional trains?

Hyperloop is better than traditional trains in many ways. It is cheaper and uses less energy because it doesn't need constant electricity. Also, hyperloop can operate like a demand-based service, with pods departing every 30 seconds.


c. Does hyperloop have a successful history? How?

No, hyperloop does not have a successful history. The original concept of using pneumatic tubes for transporting mail and parcels between buildings was a failure.


d. Write the contributions of Robert Goddard and Elon Musk for the development of hyperloop.

In the early 20th century, Robert Goddard developed the concept of the "vactrain," which is considered a precursor to the hyperloop. Elon Musk, the creator of SpaceX and Tesla, introduced the idea of the hyperloop as a fast transportation option. His publication called "Hyperloop Alpha" in 2013 sparked the concept of the hyperloop.


e. What relation does speed have with air resistance? Explain.

Air resistance slows down a moving object, so the higher the air resistance, the slower the object will go. In the case of the hyperloop, since it travels through vacuum tubes with no air, it can achieve very high speeds due to the absence of air resistance.


f. What are hyperloop capsules compared with? How are they similar?

Hyperloop capsules are compared to Boeing 747s because they both accelerate at the same rate of speed.


g. How do passengers feel while traveling via hyperloop? What will be done to make it luxurious?

Passengers feel similar to riding in an elevator or a passenger aircraft when traveling in a hyperloop. The cabins offer beautiful scenery, and each passenger has their own private entertainment system to make the journey comfortable and enjoyable.


h. Why does the writer doubt the success of hyperloop? What does success depend on?

The writer has doubts about the success of hyperloop because of the high costs involved and the fact that the projects are still in the experimental phase. Success depends on factors such as the destinations served, the local economy, and the geographical location. Past experiences with similar concepts have shown challenges in gaining government support, which raises concerns about the viability of hyperloop projects.


Critical thinking

a. Is the hyperloop the future of transportation or just a dream? What do you think? Justify your opinion with suitable reasons.


= In my opinion, the hyperloop is indeed the future of transportation. When Elon Musk introduced the concept in 2013, it sparked a lot of excitement and was seen as a futuristic mass transportation system.


One of the most impressive aspects of the hyperloop is its ability to float in tubes just a few millimeters above the ground. This technology has the potential to significantly reduce travel times between cities while being more cost-effective and environmentally friendly compared to current transportation methods. By utilizing pneumatic steel tubes, the hyperloop can achieve supersonic speeds.


However, there are still challenges to overcome. The development of the hyperloop is a costly endeavor, which may limit its accessibility to all types of travelers. Additionally, it is currently in the testing phase, and it takes time to fully realize its potential.


Despite these challenges, I believe that the hyperloop has the potential to revolutionize transportation. Throughout history, we have achieved remarkable feats and overcome seemingly impossible obstacles. If inventors and innovators succeed in their initiatives, the hyperloop could become the transportation method of the future.


b. The number of private vehicles is increasing day by day in Nepal beyond the capacity of our infrastructure. What do you think should be done to curb the ever-growing number of private vehicles? Discuss.


= Nepal is facing a rapid increase in the number of private vehicles, surpassing the capacity of its infrastructure. This rise in vehicle ownership poses significant challenges such as pollution, traffic congestion, and road accidents.


To address this issue, we need to take several steps. Firstly, it is crucial to discourage the extensive use of private vehicles due to their negative environmental impact and contribution to harmful gas emissions. Public transit should be prioritized and promoted as a viable alternative.


Implementing regulations that limit the use of older personal vehicles by municipal authorities can be beneficial. Additionally, constructing new highways and expanding existing ones can help alleviate traffic congestion. Encouraging people to utilize public transportation, such as buses and trains, is essential.


Both the government and citizens must collaborate to achieve this goal. Effective management and planning are necessary to prevent further growth in the number of vehicles and mitigate their adverse impacts. While completely stopping individuals from purchasing and using personal vehicles may not be feasible, a shift towards prioritizing public transportation is crucial for sustainable transportation in the long run.

Traditional Technologies Used by Elders in our Community


Respected Teachers and Friends,


I recently met with some elderly people in our community to learn about traditional technologies that were used in the past but are no longer in common practice. Here is a report of what I learned:


I first spoke to 75-year old Dhan Maya Lama who recalled how villagers used to grind grains manually using stone mortar and pestle called jaatika. It was laborious work but an essential part of food preparation. Now electric grinders have replaced this traditional method.


75-year old Lakh Bahadur Rai shared about how villagers extracted mustard oil in the past. Seeds were ground and pressed manually using a wooden machine called dhunki to extract the oil. This process does not require electricity unlike oil extraction machines used today.


80-year old Om Kumari Magar told me that villagers made lemon juice, tomato ketchup and jam earlier by boiling fruits and vegetables over a wooden stove called chulha which burned firewood. These food items are now easily available commercially prepared.


Finally, 80-year old Tanka Devi Bhujel described how villagers communicated manually through tin or bamboo megaphones called datbaja or omkaashi to call people from a distance. Now we use mobile phones, radios and other technologies for communication.


In conclusion, our elders performed various tasks using traditional technologies based on locally available materials that required manual labor but met their daily needs. While modern machines have made work easier, we must acknowledge and appreciate the indigenous knowledge and skills of our forefathers.

Comprehension

A. True or False or NOT GIVEN

a. The system of QR codes was first launched in South Asia. -  False

b. The standards of payments via the QR codes were approved by EMVCo. - False

B. Answer these questions.

a. How can one pay with QR codes?

To pay with QR codes, one simply needs to scan the merchant's QR code displayed at the store/stall using their mobile banking app. The app will then process the payment by deducting the amount from their bank account once they confirm the transaction.


b. How did Tencent and Alibaba companies utilise the QR code services at the beginning?

Tencent and Alibaba were early adopters of QR code payments in China. They implemented QR code standards for payments within their hugely popular messaging/mobile platforms WeChat Pay and AliPay respectively. This allowed users to easily make payments scanning codes without the need for cash or cards.


c. How do the QR code based payment services launched by Visa and Mastercard mitigate problems?

Visa and Mastercard's QR code payment services help address issues like lack of infrastructure e.g. POS machines. They allow making instant, cashless payments directly from bank accounts via a linked debit or credit card, expanding access.


d. Why do we need a scheme operator to run the QR code based payment system?

A scheme operator is needed to govern rules and standards for QR payments, authorize transactions, handle disputes and ensure interoperability between different entities like banks, wallets, merchants etc participating in the system. This helps maintain integrity, security and trust in QR payments.


e. What Basic requirements are needed to use the QR codes services?

The basic requirements are - a smartphone with an app from a participating bank/payment network and your bank account linked to that app. Many QR payment systems also allow use without needing to register beforehand for added convenience.


f. How can security concerns related to payment via QR codes be addressed?

Security can be improved by implementing user authentication, tokenization to mask real account details, encryption of data in transit, limiting payment amount without pins/biometrics, and technologies like digital signatures for non-repudiation of transactions.


g. Who should be more careful: customer or the merchant in terms of payment issues? Why?

The customer should exercise more caution since they are initiating the payment and sharing their bank account details. They need to carefully check payment amount and merchant details displayed on their phone match the actual transaction before confirming. This helps prevent errors and fraud.


h. Do you think the QR code based payment can be a panacea for all sorts of payment problems? Why?

QR code based payments have the potential to address many payment problems due to their convenience. However, for it to be a universal solution, issues like accessibility in remote areas, interoperability between different players, and protecting vulnerable users require continued innovation and regulatory oversight. Adoption also depends on awareness and literacy.

 

Critical thinking

a. Some business houses, shops and department stores in city areas have started to adopt QR code payment systems in Nepal, too. What should be done to make it more accessible? Discuss.

Here are some things that could be done to make QR code payments more accessible in Nepal:


Improve internet infrastructure: For QR codes to work smoothly, fast and reliable internet access is critical. Both broadband speed and coverage need expanding nationwide.

Increase smartphone penetration: More affordable smartphones will allow greater segments of the population to participate. Manufacturers and telecoms could offer cheaper models.

Educate users: Launch awareness drives to educate people, especially in rural areas, on using basic smartphones and QR payment apps. Demonstrate the benefits and convenience.

Simplify payment apps: Apps need very intuitive, easy-to-use interfaces that even novice users can understand. Minimum input fields and large targets to scan codes.

Interoperability: Payment networks and digital wallets must work together to ensure users can pay any merchant, not just those in their own system.

Incentivize merchants: Offer business owners incentives to set up QR infrastructure. Provide affordable POS machines and training on accepting payments.

Regulatory support: The central bank and government should support industry efforts through policies, help create standards and audit security regularly.

Alternate modes: Provide options like USSD-based payments for feature phones to expand the scope beyond smartphones.

Widespread adoption will take time but focusing on infrastructure development, education, simplification and cooperation between stakeholders can accelerate Nepal's QR payment ecosystem.

 

b. Is it possible to apply such cashless methods in payments in Nepal? Discuss.

The literacy rate of Nepal is about 65% as per the census report of 2068 BS. It implies almost 1 third of the total population does not even have got the basic education. How can we imagine Nepal being dependent on cashless Payment methods then? 

 

However, it is not hard to make payment methods digital and introduce cashless options in Nepal because the use of cash for payments is quickly being replaced by digital methods. To help Nepal's digital economy grow, QR code payments could be very important.


The main way to encourage people to use these payment methods is by teaching them how to use them. Once people are taught, they can get used to it even if they are not literate. However, many people still lack the necessary skills to handle digital payments properly, which can lead to data breaches and privacy issues, making it more complicated.


It is possible to use digital payment systems in Nepal if the lack of these facilities is addressed. To use cashless payment methods, people need a smartphone and technical knowledge, which should be accessible to everyone, including proper guidance on how to handle them securely. 

 

Writing

B. Write a news article about digital payment systems in Nepal.

 

Nepal Embraces Digital Payments

 

By Shivahari Poudel 


Kathmandu, Nepal - Digital payment systems are gaining widespread adoption across Nepal, providing many residents with a more convenient way to pay for goods and services. Industry leaders say the future of payments is moving away from cash transactions and toward platforms that enable contactless and remote payments.


"We are seeing tremendous growth in the use of digital wallets, bank transfers, and mobile payment apps in recent years," said Samir Shrestha of Khalti, one of Nepal's largest digital payment platforms. "More Nepali consumers and businesses now have the option to pay and receive payments digitally without having to handle cash."


Common digital payment methods in Nepal include mobile wallets like Khalti and eSewa, which allow users to deposit and store funds that can then be used to pay merchants online or in stores using a mobile app. Bank transfers through systems like FonePay and IME Pay enable customers to send and receive payments directly from their bank accounts. There has also been rising interest in payment tools that integrate with popular social media and messaging platforms.


The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the shift away from cash as health experts recommended contactless transactions. With ongoing concerns about virus transmission through banknotes and coins, digital payments provided a safer alternative for day-to-day purchases. Major retailers and service providers started promoting "Tap and Pay" options using digital wallets and debit/credit cards fitted with NFC chips.


Analysts say strong support from the government helped digital finance thrive in Nepal. Regulators have instituted consumer protections for digital payments while incentivizing widespread adoption through partnerships with banks, telecom firms, and startups. International remittances, a major source of funds flowing into Nepal, can now be more cheaply and easily sent via digital channels.


As technology access and literacy increases across both urban and rural Nepal, experts forecast further growth of digital payment volumes in the coming years. The convenience, safety, and financial inclusion benefits of leaving cash behind appear to be driving more Nepalis toward a cashless future.

Project Work

Browse the internet. Find out the history of money and read. Write some interesting facts about money and tell your class.

Good morning class. Today I want to share some interesting facts about the history of money.


Money as we know it today has been evolving for thousands of years. Some of the earliest forms of money were commodity currencies, where commodities like cattle, grains, or shells served as a medium of exchange. For example, cowry shells were used as currency in Africa as early as 3000 BC.


Coins were first invented in Lydia in what is now modern Turkey around 600 BC. The coins were made from electrum, a naturally occurring pale yellow alloy of gold and silver. This was one of the earliest uses of coins as currency.


Around 600-500 BC, coins began spreading to other Mediterranean civilizations like Greece and Persia. The ancient Greeks were the first to mint pure silver coins around 650-600 BC in Aegina and Athens. These silver coins helped facilitate trade throughout Greece and beyond.


In Imperial China, paper money was first used as early as the 9th century during the Tang Dynasty. Unfortunately many of these early notes were just paper receipts and not backed by currency reserves. This led to episodes of hyperinflation. It wasn't until the Ming Dynasty in the 14th century that true paper money backed by coinage became widely used.


One of the most revolutionary developments was when gold and silver standards were adopted by many economies. This started in Europe during the late Middle Ages and tied currency values to precious metals like gold and silver. The gold standard dominated the international monetary system from 1875 to 1914 prior to the First World War.


Today most of the world uses fiat currency which is not backed by any commodities, but instead holds value through regulation by central banks and faith in the government. Paper money, coins, and more recently digital currencies like bitcoin continue to evolve the way we exchange value in modern societies.

B. Answer the following questions.

People often giggle at someone's pain or suffering because laughter can be a social response, serving to relieve tension in uncomfortable or awkward situations. It's not necessarily a malicious reaction, but rather a way to cope with the discomfort of seeing someone in pain.


b. What did Scott’s study in Namibia come up with?

Scott's study in Namibia found that laughter is one of the most easily recognizable emotions across different cultures.

Laughing together also encourages couples to share personal information and build a strong bond. Laughing can also help couples cope with stress and strengthen their friendship.

There existed such a system where the trash was used to be cleaned up at a specific time at a specific place. He calls it awkward to learn their habit of not using anything second hand material, no matter if it is a car or an expensive TV set. He calls it sarcastic because people who were too shy and spirited at day time not using second hand items were also picking up things at night.


B. What are the two reasons behind the existence of Sodaigomi in Japanese culture?

Ans: The two factors behind the existence of Sodaigomi in Japanese culture were the absence of a basement, garage or extra room in the tiny Japanese home and the Japanese love for cleanliness.


C. What, according to the author, do the Japanese feel at the thought of buying second-hand items?

Ans: Japanese feel like buying second hand items as buying someone’s socks. It means they feel very timid and uncivilized to use second hand items.


D. How is Malaysian culture different from Japanese culture concerning the used items?

Ans: In Malaysia, people believe in utilizing everything and rarely throw anything away. Even expensive items are valued and not easily discarded. Malaysians enthusiastically bid on second-hand items in auctions. On the other hand, in Japan, even expensive items are often thrown away, and second-hand items are looked down upon, similar to used socks.


E. Why did the author feel awkward at the sodaigomi pile?

Ans: The author felt awkward at the sodaigomi pile because he wanted to take things he needed, but it went against the typical Japanese culture of not using second-hand items. This made him feel uncomfortable.


F. How many articles did the author bring to his house one after another?

Ans: The author brought several items to his house, including tea, an expensive chair, a new bicycle bell, a small wooden cabinet, a complete set of wrenches and screwdrivers in a metal toolbox, a Naugahyde-covered barstool, a lacquer serving tray, bookshelves, televisions, and more.


G. Why do most people try to find things in the trash pile ‘in the dead of the night’?

Ans:  Most people try to find things in the trash in the dead of the night because not everyone can afford to always use first and fresh items. Another reason was, that was the time when people had no shame or mocking at picking up things that were needed.


H. How did the author’s family assimilate Japanese culture in using consumer goods?

Ans: Assimilate means to digest or to be habitual with. The Author’s family assimilated with Japanese Culture in using consumer goods by picking up things at night and being luxurious in day time, like the Japanese did. Consumed goods are not used by the majority of Japanese citizens. But, some used to pick up trash at night because they are not supervised. 


Critical thinking 

a. If you happen to be in Japan someday, will you collect articles from sodaigomi? Why or why not?

Ans: It depends upon the situation. If I happen to be in Japan someday, I will surely collect articles from sodaigomi if I have no or average financial strength. For various reasons (education, job, etc.), many citizens from Nepal move to Japan. Money management is a problem for them. To save money, I will probably utilize second-hand products, since they have a lot of essentials. In order to avoid detection, I may collect them without anybody noticing. Using an used item is not a sin in my culture.  


b. There are some second hand shops in Nepal, too. But, people are not much interested in them. What practice would be suitable in managing second hand items in Nepal?

Ans: There are several reasons why people in Nepal are hesitant to buy from second-hand shops. Firstly, there is a sense of shame associated with purchasing used items. People fear judgment from others when they are seen buying second-hand products. Additionally, sellers at these shops are often unreliable and make false promises about the quality and durability of the items they sell.


To effectively manage second-hand items in Nepal, we should normalize the practice of buying used goods. We should not feel ashamed or embarrassed about using these products. While it's important to avoid purchasing items that are in poor condition, we can confidently buy second-hand furniture, electrical equipment, and cars that are in good shape. By changing our attitudes and shopping habits, we can embrace the value and benefits of second-hand items.


Writing

a. Write a paragraph focusing on the concept of waste management using the 3rs (reduce, reuse, and recycle).

The 3Rs approach of reduce, reuse and recycle provides an effective strategy for waste management and environmental protection. Reducing the amount of waste generated in the first place is the most important of the 3Rs. This can be done by choosing products with less packaging, avoiding single-use items, and reducing consumption in general. For items that can no longer be used for their original purpose, reusing them wherever possible extends their lifespan and keeps useful materials out of landfills. Examples include reusing plastic bags, glass jars, clothing, and electronics. Finally, ensuring items are recycled at the end of their useful life is crucial. Recycling recovers materials and transforms waste into new products or raw materials. If everyone were to consistently apply the 3Rs in their daily lives and industries optimized waste reduction, the quantity of trash ending up in landfills or polluting the environment could be significantly decreased. This sustainable approach benefits both the environment and the health of communities.


b. In most of Nepal's cities, waste management is a major issue. Write a letter to the editor to be published in the daily newspaper suggesting ways of ‘Solving Garbage Problems.’

Tinkune-5, Kathmandu

16, November 2021

To the editor,

Himalayan Daily,

Kathmandu, Nepal


Subject: To publish my article on garbage management in Nepal.


Dear Sir,

It’s not necessary to remind you that the Nepalese capital, Kathmandu, has been plagued by waste for the last 20 years, but now the whole country is affected. Not only the city inhabitants but also the foreigners and tourists have an unfavorable impression of our city because it is littered with waste. I'll go through some of the best strategies to avoid the issue of garbage here. I'd appreciate it if you published my article on Garbage management, which is a major issue in most of Nepal's major cities.


Garbage has many sources, in which household, industries, hospitals, vehicles are the major. First, we should separate the garbage on the basis of its nature. If it is organic, we can use it to make manures and if it is inorganic, we could either use the 3RS method, or simply use the incineration method, which will cause less smoke to burn down the trash.


First idea is compost manure preparation:

Biodegradable trash may be used to provide economic advantages. Composting or vermin composting may be used to turn organic waste into compost from solid waste or rubbish. Rural farmers have long used compost to generate manure. Being farmers, we should prioritize compost manure over inorganic fertilizers.


Second option is to use landfill.

In landfills, garbage is buried beneath the surface of the ground.  Pits or man-made pits are often utilized for landfilling. A well-managed landfill may be both sanitary and cost-effective for disposing of waste.


Third method is to utilize the usable trash

Electricity and heat could be produced by the waste. Both the production of more energy from rubbish waste and the reduction of Nepal's garbage waste issue are enhanced as a result of this approach.


Fourth option is incineration

An incinerator is a device that burns rubbish and other solid organic waste with less smoke production. This procedure is carried out in a sterile setting. This is the most used way for disposing of medical and industrial waste. The heat generated during the process may be utilized as a power source, while the ash that is left over can be used as fertilizer in agriculture. There is a potential that Nepal's garbage problem may be solved.


I am optimistic for the positive response from the respected editor and can’t wait to see this article in your next publication. 

Sincerely,

Ram Sharma

Inhabitant of Kathmandu Valley

Critical thinking 

a. Suppose you are Julia Butterfly Hill. After staying one year in the tree, the government offered you five million dollars and requested you to drop the strike. Write in about 200 words responding to them that the money is a mean thing for you in comparison with the woods.

I appreciate your offer to end my sit-in for 5 million dollars. However, money means little to me compared to protecting these magnificent redwood trees. I have endured over a year of difficult conditions in Luna to save her from being cut down. I have faced threats, harassment and the harsh forces of nature. Yet none of these hardships mattered as much to me as seeing this beautiful old-growth tree standing tall.


I did not take up residence in Luna for personal gain or recognition. My goal has always been to draw attention to the plight of the redwood forests and stop their senseless destruction. Clear cutting these ecologically important trees must end in order to protect the environment and wildlife. Offering me money ignores the real issue confronting the woods I care so deeply about.


As long as logging continues, my protest will continue as well. No amount of money can replace what has already been lost or undo the damage done. I ask that you use the $5 million for conservation instead, such as purchasing threatened redwood lands or replanting cut areas. c. What are the different areas where CV can help you?

A CV can help you in different areas like getting a job, promotion or research funding. Organizations also use your CV to understand your qualifications and accomplishments when deciding if you are suitable for something.


d. What do you mean by 'staying CV' and 'leaving CV'? Which one would you develop for yourself as a freshman?

A 'staying CV' focuses more on committee work and administration experience while a 'leaving CV' highlights your research achievements and overall competence. As a freshman, I would create a 'leaving CV' to showcase my abilities and willingness to perform different academic tasks.


e. How can you draft a good CV?

To draft a good CV, I will organize all necessary information well and write it clearly in the proper format. I will also get ideas from experienced people to make my CV quality.


f. What is the difference between academic CV and non-academic CV?

Academic CVs are usually longer than non-academic CVs. They become more detailed over time. Non-academic CVs often just describe skills and qualities but academic CVs provide verifiable proofs of accomplishments and achievements.


Critical thinking

a. CV may not represent a person’s skills and abilities accurately because one’s confidence cannot be rendered in a paper. What do you think employers should do to find the best people for the job?

While a CV shows qualifications and experience, it doesn't show how confident someone is. To find the best people, employers should also conduct interviews to directly assess candidates' skills, personality and fit for the role. This allows employers to learn more about the person beyond what's on paper and help identify those with the right qualifications and personality for the job.


b. If the employers provide job opportunities by assessing one’s CV, how can fresh graduates compete with the experienced competitors?

To compete with experienced people when companies look at resumes, fresh graduates can do several things to make their resumes stand out. They should focus on discussing their recent education in school, mentioning classes that are relevant to the job. It's also important to include any internships, part-time work, or class projects that can demonstrate real experience. Fresh graduates should pick and highlight the skills, certificates, and training that are most useful for the position. They need to customize their resume for each job by changing it to match what the company is asking for in the job description. They can describe their work and successes using strong verbs to make it more engaging. Where possible, they should add numbers or percentages to showcase what they achieved quantitatively. Soft skills like adapting, communicating, and working in a team, which are valuable for any job, should also be mentioned. Networking through events, LinkedIn, and job groups can help make new connections. Asking teachers, past bosses or mentors for referrals or recommendations for companies. Finally, showing a commitment to continuous learning and improving one's skills on an ongoing basis. By focusing on these areas, fresh graduates can make their resumes competitive against candidates with more work experience when applying for jobs.

COMPREHENSION 


Answer the following questions. 

a. What is the author’s favourite hobby?


The author's favorite hobby is walking. She likes it because it provides a physical sensation she enjoys, the movement, rhythm, and undulation of the senses and body.


b. What sorts of roads did the writer prefer to walk on when she was very young?


When the writer was very young, she preferred to walk on unpaved and uneven roads, like the paths around her mamaghar.


c. How did walking give the author and her classmates a sense of freedom?


Walking gave the author and her classmates a sense of freedom because they took shortcuts and chose their own way during their walks home from school, which felt like a protest against their regimented routine.


d. In what ways were the roads in Kathmandu different from the ones in Sydney?


The roads in Kathmandu were unpaved and uneven, while in Sydney, they were quieter, more organized, and had both old and new elements.


e. How did walking help the author in the new country?


Walking helped the author in the new country (Australia) by allowing her to explore and navigate her surroundings, helping her find her way in a new place.


f. What were the treasures of Petersham, where the writer lived with her family?


The treasures of Petersham, where the writer lived with her family, included a tiny park and another park with a huge rock, providing a buffer zone and a place to hide.


g. What things became her permanent friends with whom she could share her feelings?


The earth and the sky, the trees, water, and the physical and natural world became the author's permanent friends with whom she could share her feelings during her solitary walks.


h. Why did she feel that she had travelled to ‘a desert, to emptiness’ as she went to the United States?


The author felt that she had traveled to 'a desert, to emptiness' in the United States because her experiences were new and unexpected, making her feel alone and in search of grounding.


i. Why did the author eventually feel that the strange city was known to her?


Even though the city was strange to her, the author felt that the place itself was known to her, and she sensed the spirits of those who had lived there before.


j. How did walking make her feel at home with different places she visited?


Walking made the author feel at home with different places she visited because it allowed her to connect with the natural and physical world, reminding her of her intrinsic self regardless of where she was.


CRITICAL THINKING 


a. Do you believe that walking helps us understand ourselves? Give reasons in support of your opinion. 


Yes, I believe that walking helps us understand ourselves better for a few reasons:


Walking allows time for reflection. When we walk, particularly alone, it gives our minds a chance to wander and think without many external distractions. This reflection time can provide insight into who we are, what we value, and how we view the world.


It promotes mindfulness of our body and surroundings. The rhythmic physical activity of walking combined with being outdoors makes us more attuned to bodily sensations and the natural environment. This mindfulness can translate to greater self-awareness.


It fosters connection to place. By walking the same paths over time, we start to feel more grounded and "at home" wherever we are, whether familiar or new surroundings. This sense of connection and comfort with place may mirror how we learn to feel more connected and comfortable with ourselves.


b. Think of one of your hobbies. How does this hobby relate to your psyche and self? 


I enjoy practicing yoga as one of my hobbies. It is connected to my mind and self because it allows me to relax while still being productive. Doing yoga makes me look and feel better physically while also reducing stress levels.


Yoga is beneficial for reducing stress and anxiety and can help when coping with depression. It gives me an opportunity for self-improvement. Yoga is good for developing one's personality as it makes us mentally stronger and more self-sufficient by overcoming obstacles in life and enhancing our inner creativity and hidden talents.


Yoga is an excellent way to unwind spiritually and mentally, as well as to enhance both physical and mental health. It can help prevent high blood pressure and improves overall wellness. The relaxing practices help clear the mind while also strengthening the body. Regular yoga sessions provide holistic benefits to both mental and physical health.


c. Many people turn their hobbies into careers. Is it good to turn one's hobby into a career? 


Turning a hobby into a career can be a great idea, but it's not always the best choice for everyone. Here are some simple explanations of the pros and cons:


Good things about turning a hobby into a career:


Passion: If you love what you do, working on your hobby can be very enjoyable and fulfilling.


Motivation: You might be more motivated to work hard and improve because you genuinely enjoy it.


Creative Freedom: Turning your hobby into a job can give you more control and freedom in how you work.


Potential Income: If your hobby is in demand, it can potentially make you money.


Bad things:


Pressure: When your hobby becomes a job, there can be more pressure to perform, which might take away some of the fun.


Financial Risk: Not all hobbies make good careers, so there's a risk of financial instability.


Burnout: Doing something you love too much can sometimes lead to burnout, where you get tired of it.


Uncertainty: Turning a hobby into a job might change your relationship with it, and you might lose the joy you once had.


In the end, it depends on your unique situation and how much you're willing to take on the challenges that come with turning a hobby into a career. Some people find it incredibly rewarding, while others prefer to keep their hobbies separate from their work.


Writing

Highlighting the advantages of walking, Henry David Thoreau says, “An early- morning walk is a blessing for the whole day.” Write an essay on the advantages of morning walk.


Title : The Advantages of Morning Walk


Thoreau was right when he said that an early-morning walk is a blessing for the whole day. Taking a walk in the morning has considerable physical, mental and emotional benefits. He understood intuitively what modern science has proven - that morning physical activity can drastically improve both health and productivity.


One of the major advantages of a morning walk is that it helps to energize the body. When we wake up, our bodies are still sluggish from sleep. Going for a walk gets the blood circulating and releases endorphins that boost energy levels. The increased oxygen flow reinvigorates muscles and organs. This leaves us feeling refreshed and ready to take on the day ahead. Morning walkers report feeling more alert and less tired throughout the day compared to those who skip their walks.


In addition to physical energy, a morning walk also provides mental clarity. Light exercise has been shown to increase blood flow to the brain. This enhances cognition and focus. Scientific studies have found correlations between regular morning exercise and improved memory, problem-solving skills and mood. While going for a walk, we are also exposed to sunlight which aids in regulating circadian rhythms and serotonin production. This positively impacts our mental well-being.


Emotional wellness is another benefit. Spending time in nature has calming and stress-reducing effects. The solitude of a morning walk allows us to clear our minds of worries and mentally prepare for the day. Low impact activities like walking simultaneously boost endorphins and diminish stress hormones like cortisol. Over time, morning walkers report feeling more positive, relaxed and emotionally balanced compared to non-walkers. This improved mood carries over throughout the day and we are able to face challenges with renewed optimism.


In summary, a daily morning walk offers considerable physical, mental and emotional advantages that enrich both health and productivity. By dedicating just 30 minutes to soak in the early light and fresh air, we are rewarded with renewed energy, focus, well-being and clarity of thought to handle our daily lives. Thoreau was truly perceptive in recognizing walking's ability to bless the entirety of one's day.

Event: The 1934 Nepal–Bihar earthquake


When did it happen: On January 15, 1934


Why did it happen: This earthquake was caused by movement along the Main Frontal Thrust fault zone located in western Nepal. Fault movements during earthquakes occur due to a build up of stresses in the earth's crust over centuries. This particular fault ruptured, releasing energy in the form of seismic waves, causing tremendous shaking and damage.


What were the consequences: This earthquake had a magnitude of 8.0 on the Richter scale. It is considered one of the deadliest earthquakes to have hit the region. Official estimates report that over 8,500 people lost their lives due to the quake and many more were injured. Hundreds of thousands were left homeless as vast rural areas suffered massive damage with mudbrick houses collapsing. Critical infrastructure like roads, health facilities and temples were destroyed. Entire villages were wiped out by landslides and ground fractures triggered by the earthquake. Relief and rescue efforts were hampered due to the remote location and lack of resources at the time. The event caused devastating losses and long term impacts on the economy and living standards in Nepal and also neighboring regions of India.


In conclusion, the powerful 1934 Nepal-Bihar earthquake was a tragic event that led to immense loss of life and property due to the region's vulnerability to quakes combined with lack of preparedness at the time. The impact underlined the need for improved earthquake safety measures.

Private and Public Schools in Nepal 


Nepal's education system should strive to provide equal opportunities and quality education for all citizens, regardless of their economic or social backgrounds. Some steps that could help make education more equitable include:


Expanding access to free public schools across the country. Currently, public schools are lacking in rural areas, making education inaccessible for many poor families. The government should prioritize building more public schools even in remote villages to ensure every child can attend school nearby.


Improving the standards of public school education. Public schools need adequate funding, infrastructure, well-trained teachers and up-to-date learning materials to improve learning outcomes. A quality education in public schools can help remove the need for expensive private schools that are out of reach for most.


Providing subsidized college education. Higher education remains unaffordable for many despite scholarships. The government could directly subsidize a certain number of seats in public colleges or offer student loans at nominal interest rates to financially support meritorious students from poorer backgrounds.


Implementing targeted programs to boost enrollment of underprivileged groups. For example, girls from rural areas face socio-economic barriers that prevent their schooling. Strategies like stipends conditional to school attendance can encourage families to educate their daughters.


An equitable and inclusive education system is crucial for Nepal to develop an informed citizenry and a just society. With sustained efforts, all Nepali children can have equal access to learning regardless of their financial circumstances.

Nepal's Role in Peace-Building


Introduction

Nepal is committed to promoting peace both within its borders and around the world. As the birthplace of Lord Buddha, a central figure of peace, Nepal considers non-violence and harmony among all people as fundamental principles.


United Nations Peacekeeping Operations

Nepal has been actively involved in UN peacekeeping missions since 1958. Currently, there are around 5,000 Nepali soldiers and police serving under the UN flag in various hotspots like South Sudan, Lebanon and Cyprus. Their responsibilities include monitoring ceasefires, protecting civilians and aid workers. Nepali peacekeepers are renowned for their bravery and professionalism.


Diplomacy and Mediation

Nepal firmly believes in the power of dialogue and diplomatic outreach to resolve conflicts. It has acted as a mediator between conflicting parties in South Asia. Nepal also advocates for open communication channels between countries facing tensions. Most recently, it organized a track 1.5 dialogue between India and China to ease border tensions.


Disarmament Initiatives

To curb spread of illicit weapons, Nepal is party to international treaties against landmines, cluster munitions and other arms. It also runs awareness campaigns on dangers of explosive remnants of war. Nepal worked with civil society to voluntary destroy over 5,000 explosive devices found within its territory.


Global Teachings of Lord Buddha

Nepal shares Buddha's message of non-violence, compassion, harmony and peaceful co-existence around the world. It plays an active part in global Buddhist organizations promoting these ideals which can counter forces of intolerance and extremism.


Conclusion

Through its actions both at home and abroad, Nepal upholds the image of a responsible, neutral powerhouse for peace as envisioned byLord Buddha, its greatest son. The country will continue utilizing diplomatic, cultural and UN-centric means to reduce conflicts and build an era of amity between all people.

Diaspora generally refers to the dispersion of a population from its original homeland. Dediasporization would involve efforts to repatriate or reconnect a dispersed population group back to its ancestral lands or culture. It is Mary's belief that white women are the real source of power and background for all females, whereas non-white women's history are only notable as instances of female oppression. Lorde disagrees with Mary's point of view because she believes that Mary has shown the superiority of white feminism over black feminism by treating black people as if they were ornaments and neglecting their suffering and oppression. Lorde believes that Mary's position is inherently racist.


h. What is Afrekete? How does it connect to this lesson?

Afrekete is the voice of black lesbian literary tradition. This lesson "An Open Letter to Mary Daly" is linked to this one in the sense that the author wishes to unite all the black women in the arena of black literature by using this method of communication.


CRITICAL THINKING 


a. "The oppression of women knows no ethnic or racial boundaries." Do you agree or not? Justify with your reasons. 


The mistreatment of women exists across all ethnicities and races. However, the type and level of mistreatment may differ based on other factors like a woman's background.


All women deal with some common problems. But a Black woman's experience will not always be exactly the same as an Asian or White woman's. Things like a person's job, income level, sexual orientation, and race can also impact how they are treated.


During the coronavirus pandemic in America, this has been especially clear. Many important frontline jobs, like working in grocery stores or delivering food, are done by women of color. They have faced greater risks because of their gender and ethnicity.


While all women worldwide deal with issues related to their gender, each individual woman's situation is unique. A woman's race, economic status, and other parts of who she is affect the specific challenges she faces. So although mistreatment crosses ethnic boundaries, the nature and degree of it varies considerably depending on a woman's full identity and circumstances.


Writing 

A. Have you ever faced or witnessed cases of racial or sexual discrimination? Write a short account. 


When I was in university, I witnessed an act of racial discrimination towards one of my classmates. Jane was a talented student from an ethnic minority background. During a group project presentation, one of the other students constantly interrupted and undermined Jane's comments, dismissing her ideas without good reason. It seemed clear the intent was to sabotage Jane's contributions just because of her race.


As Jane's friend, it upset me to see her treated that way for no reason other than the color of her skin. She worked very hard and deserved to be judged based on her abilities, not attributes beyond her control. Events like that taught me discrimination remains a problem, and showed how much harm it can cause both emotionally and in terms of opportunities for those targeted. It's important that as a society we continue efforts to promote inclusion and fairness for all.


B. Write an article for a national daily on "The Status of Women in Nepali Society." 


The Status of Women in Nepali Society 


Kathmandu, 13th August , 2023


Women's status varies according to geography, caste, economy, religion, and social structure. Nepal's standing as a country for women cannot be praised highly enough. More than 60% of women are uneducated.


In principle, they are equal under the constitution, but in practice, they are not. They cannot participate in public affairs because of the dominant cultural mindset. They have remained hidden because of the caste system, traditional eating customs, and the focus on virginity.


Among their chores include cooking, laundry, and kid care. Family breadwinners are males, whereas women are only considered as domestic and maternity carers. Women must work at home. Hindu women are meant to be financially dependent on males from birth to death. Household duties include gathering wood and fuel for fireplaces, transporting water, gardening, and assisting males and other family members.


Nepalese women are also pushed into prostitution and sold as commercial sexworkers due to harsh legislation. They work 16 hours a day in agriculture, carpet manufacturing, and wage labor.


In a nutshell, Mahatma Gandhi said that man and woman are the two wheels of a cart that must operate together. Mothers in particular guide the rest of the family. As a consequence, without adequate education and economic rights for women, the family cannot flourish.
